content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is an implementation of `q_and_a_extractor` function that will solve your problem:

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md)
    lines = split(md, '\n')
    question = ""
    answer = ""
    in_question = false
    in_answer = false

    for line in lines
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            in_question = true
        elseif startswith(line, "# Answer")
            in_question = false
            in_answer = true
        else
            if in_question && !isempty(strip(line))
                question *= strip(line)
            elseif in_answer && !isempty(strip(line))
                answer *= strip(line)
            end
        end
    end

    return (question, answer)
end
```
This function splits the markdown text into lines and iterates over each line. If a line starts with "# Question", it sets `in_question` to true and if it starts with "# Answer", it sets `in_answer` to true. It then appends the stripped version of the line to either `question` or `answer` depending on whether we are currently in a question or an answer section.

Note: This function assumes that there is only one `# Question` and one `# Answer` in the markdown text, and ignores any other lines that might start with these prefixes. If your markdown can contain multiple questions and answers, you would need to modify this function accordingly.
